revised_title: Interferometric Examination of Cleavage Faces of Mica and Selenite
tldr: The authors used multiple beam interferometry to examine the topography of cleavage faces of mica and selenite crystals. They discovered hills and dales, sharp cleavage lines representing discontinuities in level, and highly uniform areas between these lines. The smallest step measured was 41 A units, and the precision attained was extremely high, particularly in the case of mica. This research provides valuable insights into the mechanism of cleavage in crystals.
